type="narrative" name="plainTextNarrative"><xField name="text"><xString value="Hi, thanks for coming, I'm Daniel Vigovszky..
I'm going to talk today about how we use Scala to keep our document system consistent on all platforms while it is continously evolving.
"/></xField></xConstructor></xJust></xField></xFields></flyToOverview><flyToObject><xFields><xField name="narrative"><xJust><xConstructor type="narrative" name="plainTextNarrative"><xField name="text"><xString value="So let's see the agenda:
- First I'd like to talk a few word about who we are,
- Then give a little context, what problem we are trying to solve
- then  I'm going to introduce you all the layers of testing we are doing win our system, and although it will be a specific example, I hope you will find some parts of it useful for other domains as well.
- Finally I'll give you some advice that we found very useful in the past years"/></xField></xConstructor></xJust></xField></xFields><target><ref value="11165545991907550F05DB28263B7CF0"/></target></flyToObject><flyToObject><xFields><xField name="narrative"><xJust><xConstructor type="narrative" name="plainTextNarrative"><xField name="text"><xString value="I work @ Prezi in the Coedit team, we are responsible for 
collaborative editing o prezis 
and other document services (conversion)

and I also worked in the last year on making Scala a standard, accepted backend technology at prezi

The team has 7 developers in Budapest

and now we are primarily using scala

but used to have lot of Haskell

and also work on these other languages"/></xField></xConstructor></xJust></xField></xFields><actions><array><fadeInObject><target><ref value="2870190D2D4B81F1BB66070C195E0C57"/></target></fadeInObject><fadeInObject><target><ref value="200B2E6016879C2E1A70E13A150369A0"/></target></fadeInObject><xConstructor name="fadeInObjects" type="pathAction"><xField name="targets"><xArray><xRef value="20FFA1CAFF4D6E05B8C6A75799D17282"/><xRef value="720849125"/></xArray></xField></xConstructor><xConstructor name="fadeInObjects" type="pathAction"><xField name="targets"><xArray><xRef value="227604206"/><xRef value="289DD72AD2ED19D7461087439D718BFE"/></xArray></xField></xConstructor><fadeInObject><target><ref value="E2EFD65557190C5747DB266D12DC2009"/></target></fadeInObject></array></actions><target><ref value="D95E333F3F3FDD5292940330A3762002"/></target></flyToObject><flyToOverview><xFields><xField name="narrative"><xJust><xConstructor type="narrative" name="plainTextNarrative"><xField name="text"><xString value="Hi, thanks for coming, I'm Daniel Vigovszky..
I'm going to talk today about how we use Scala to keep our document system consistent on all platforms while it is continously evolving.
"/></xField></xConstructor></xJust></xField></xFields></flyToOverview><flyToObject><xFields><xField name="narrative"><xJust><xConstructor type="narrative" name="plainTextNarrative"><xField name="text"><xString value="Let me introduce the domain we are in, and why is it hard"/></xField></xConstructor></xJust></xField></xFields><target><ref value="3BBE7336B926A2E99F8E2AE1FF6A2670"/></target></flyToObject><flyToObject><xFields><xField name="narrative"><xJust><xConstructor type="narrative" name="plainTextNarrative"><xField name="text"><xString value="PDOM is Prezi's document object model

It is an in-memory representation, you probably can all imagine that

serialization to xml

additional services like undoredo

..consistency checks

implements a network protocol for collaborative editing"/></xField></xConstructor></xJust></xField></xFields><actions><array><fadeInObject><target><ref value="BF504979ADB14FCE0100461AA68B5CA8"/></target></fadeInObject><xConstructor name="fadeInObjects" type="pathAction"><xField name="targets"><xArray><xRef value="420282B0CBB27B769B257A044930F626"/><xRef value="503629543"/></xArray></xField></xConstructor><fadeInObject><target><ref value="7D5E7DF01989F3DCEAF3392CC1625396"/></target></fadeInObject><fadeInObject><target><ref value="4404588B5BA6918407BAF1AC89C47BA1"/></target></fadeInObject><fadeInObject><target><ref value="0BCC77495CF2105E23C1AE2988038252"/></target></fadeInObject></array></actions><target><ref value="DC347170592C59A35464A6E2756C0984"/></target></flyToObject><flyToObject><xFields><xField name="narrative"><xJust><xConstructor type="narrative" name="plainTextNarrative"><xField name="text"><xString value="What platforms are working on?

And for the editor, we have both:

browser based

and a desktop
.. and although both are based on the same codebase, there can be still differences like in how offline mode and retries are handled."/></xField></xConstructor></xJust></xField></xFields><actions><array><xConstructor name="fadeInObjects" type="pathAction"><xField name="targets"><xArray><xRef value="22BE9751F6951A8B5B4A2473D5C3314C"/><xRef value="FB699F8DA1D402A6851624F30F0DD4F6"/></xArray></xField></xConstructor><xConstructor name="fadeInObjects" type="pathAction"><xField name="targets"><xArray><xRef value="23BA6B86658AB5300C869D55E60E0C99"/><xRef value="252143564"/><xRef value="447380002"/></xArray></xField></xConstructor><xConstructor name="fadeInObjects" type="pathAction"><xField name="targets"><xArray><xRef value="53125133"/><xRef value="C8FE7BD163E4C962014899B3C821E8DD"/></xArray></xField></xConstructor><xConstructor name="fadeInObjects" type="pathAction"><xField name="targets"><xArray><xRef value="497679039"/><xRef value="566F559316909BA8D217EE5FAF77EC6B"/></xArray></xField></xConstructor><xConstructor name="zoomToObject" type="pathAction"><xField name="target"><xRef value="6360CA175A1C54D107ED0951E76F1D40"/></xField></xConstructor><xConstructor name="fadeInObjects" type="pathAction"><xField name="targets"><xArray><xRef value="13782CFD6B77930550717E65DCD9D445"/><xRef value="59731FFDF436F859369C1735CA335089"/></xArray></xField></xConstructor><xConstructor name="zoomToObject" type="pathAction"><xField name="target"><xRef value="BE3205A70C4A9EBB8D6F6CC7E5DFC5E5"/></xField></xConstructor></array></actions><target><ref value="BE3205A70C4A9EBB8D6F6CC7E5DFC5E5"/></target></flyToObject><flyToObject><xFields><xField name="narrative"><xJust><xConstructor type="narrative" name="plainTextNarrative"><xField name="text"><xString value="So we have a PDOM implementation for all these platforms, and we want to do collaborative editing, or coedit

OT algorithms, same as what's behind goodle docs

The goals is to keep the doc consistent

they can be different desktop versions 

connections are unstable
(and I put the akka logo here just because our coedit service takes a heavy usage of it ;)

So that's all about the domain, and let's see how do we make all this work."/></xField></xConstructor></xJust></xField></xFields><actions><array><fadeInObject><target><ref value="F44FE955E1AF177D27DC160D47E2C901"/></target></fadeInObject><fadeInObject><target><ref value="EBBBF9770A2A8284DB70893F078A5323"/></target></fadeInObject><fadeInObject><target><ref value="8E1F09DAF17E0C74286FA5C91C9E508C"/></target></fadeInObject><fadeInObject><target><ref value="D36FB6E638D2181E344DEF2DAE321CD4"/></target></fadeInObject></array></actions><target><ref value="48E91D8C1DB6426AFD67ED4C0E4A8657"/></target></flyToObject><flyToOverview><xFields><xField name="narrative"><xJust><xConstructor type="narrative" name="plainTextNarrative"><xField name="text"><xString value="Hi, thanks for coming, I'm Daniel Vigovszky..
I'm going to talk today about how we use Scala to keep our document system consistent on all platforms while it is continously evolving.
"/></xField></xConstructor></xJust></xField></xFields></flyToOverview><flyToObject><xFields><xField name="narrative"><xJust><xConstructor type="narrative" name="plainTextNarrative"><xField name="text"><xString value="Let's talk about all the layers of steps and tests we perform."/></xField></xConstructor></xJust></xField></xFields><target><ref value="8258F43C81EBDBA79A6F619645735C57"/></target></flyToObject><flyToObject><xFields><xField name="narrative"><xJust><xConstructor type="narrative" name="plainTextNarrative"><xField name="text"><xString value="First of all, we have a schema of Prezi documents.
There is a DSL that describes it, modified by all the editor developers

First it was Haskell

Now there is a Scala version too (it less like a DSL - we have to find the balance here, good IDE support is often better than a fully customized syntax, for non Scala developers)

---> Talk about the example code

1. The DSL itself limits what can be expressed in the schema by its type sys
2. We perform additional checks on build time"/></xField></xConstructor></xJust></xField></xFields><actions><array><xConstructor name="fadeInObjects" type="pathAction"><xField name="targets"><xArray><xRef value="158297223"/><xRef value="598436386"/></xArray></xField></xConstructor><xConstructor name="zoomToObject" type="pathAction"><xField name="target"><xRef value="598436386"/></xField></xConstructor><xConstructor name="zoomToObject" type="pathAction"><xField name="target"><xRef value="6324AA4E6D8CE1E7B8B9F7180964177D"/></xField></xConstructor><xConstructor name="zoomToObject" type="pathAction"><xField name="target"><xRef value="58934ACB543749F93C3FEFE6036C899E"/></xField></xConstructor><xConstructor name="zoomToObject" type="pathAction"><xField name="target"><xRef value="B650C3C5D32D2B32DA3EAAB1E0DF1701"/></xField></xConstructor><xConstructor name="fadeInObjects" type="pathAction"><xField name="targets"><xArray><xRef value="0EC82F024391F6C146645B05FB085B7F"/><xRef value="2970D1CB05B99F8E913104AD9B06EC65"/></xArray></xField></xConstructor><xConstructor name="fadeInObjects" type="pathAction"><xField name="targets"><xArray><xRef value="9FF65F0923652CBBA28291F1268C4608"/><xRef value="EA4FC596C89CD19D847BA5F2F6DFD223"/></xArray></xField></xConstructor></array></actions><target><ref value="B650C3C5D32D2B32DA3EAAB1E0DF1701"/></target></flyToObject><flyToObject><xFields><xField name="narrative"><xJust><xConstructor type="narrative" name="plainTextNarrative"><xField name="text"><xString value="Once we know our schema, the next step is to have a PDOM library for all the platforms.

Generating code from the schema
(with templating - I will explain why a bit later)

--> List all the targets

Everything generated at this step is then going through a compiler and unit tested
So we can be sure after this point that all platforms are always implementing the same schema

You could ask why templating, why not use scala macros for example?"/></xField></xConstructor></xJust></xField></xFields><actions><array><xConstructor name="zoomToObject" type="pathAction"><xField name="target"><xRef value="48A59ED554C160DF629137F9C31B0822"/></xField></xConstructor><xConstructor name="zoomToObject" type="pathAction"><xField name="target"><xRef value="7B7302F11210ADE4DFAC15BAF6967B80"/></xField></xConstructor><fadeInObject><target><ref value="E4C152537611AC0EA29789B52929E788"/></target></fadeInObject><fadeInObject><target><ref value="89D5E126C684C16A511C6609AAB4B4F9"/></target></fadeInObject><xConstructor name="fadeInObjects" type="pathAction"><xField name="targets"><xArray><xRef value="0196C0DA7F0E4A7838ADC8204D12BB32"/><xRef value="3260FD1A43319B970A74DFD10761758A"/><xRef value="670A146052A440B916F5AF7122FB2DDB"/><xRef value="7E9288A17ABB1FE0C90095F375E000A5"/><xRef value="80C09FA07AE5A2F12227DFE6824F09B0"/><xRef value="84770035DD9D4BF5CEBE98FB78EAB409"/><xRef value="9DC5712F648C7811C4B4FDC94695B4A6"/><xRef value="F8F00FE2AECF98F9B24EE48A38D6D5E5"/></xArray></xField></xConstructor><xConstructor name="zoomToObject" type="pathAction"><xField name="target"><xRef value="F8F00FE2AECF98F9B24EE48A38D6D5E5"/></xField></xConstructor><xConstructor name="zoomToObject" type="pathAction"><xField name="target"><xRef value="7B7302F11210ADE4DFAC15BAF6967B80"/></xField></xConstructor></array></actions><target><ref value="7B7302F11210ADE4DFAC15BAF6967B80"/></target></flyToObject><flyToObject><xFields><xField name="narrative"><xJust><xConstructor type="narrative" name="plainTextNarrative"><xField name="text"><xString value="As I mentioned we are using OT algorithms. It works like the clients are sending patches and there are some basic laws that these patches must comply with.

Don't go in details, but what I want to show is..

ScalaCheck - property based testing

Two steps: 
1. ability to generate arbitrary patches (and documents) (first: hand written generic, second: generated)

2. writing the laws (simple, but not the real one, a simple real one, a more complex one)"/></xField></xConstructor></xJust></xField></xFields><actions><array><xConstructor name="zoomToObject" type="pathAction"><xField name="target"><xRef value="1693B790AFEB48AA82709235E51AE1BD"/></xField></xConstructor><xConstructor name="zoomToObject" type="pathAction"><xField name="target"><xRef name="text"><xString value="Even if we are now confident that our PDOM libraries implement the same schema and the OT algorithms are behaving, we need a proof that on all platforms it works exactly the same.

And here is an idea that pretty well worked for us: test multiplatform behavior with one of the platforms' prop based test fw

First example: XML serialization, explain

Second: generalized

Examples of application"/></xField></xConstructor></xJust></xField></xFields><actions><array><fadeInObject><target><ref value="CC5E01BDD6A5D7CB2E2DF473805580AB"/></target></fadeInObject><fadeInObject><target><ref value="903167847"/></target></fadeInObject><xConstructor name="zoomToObject" type="pathAction"><xField name="target"><xRef value="903167847"/></xField></xConstructor><fadeInObject><target><ref value="706194592"/></target></fadeInObject><xConstructor name="zoomToObject" type="pathAction"><xField name="target"><xRef value="706194592"/></xField></xConstructor><xConstructor name="zoomToObject" type="pathAction"><xField name="target"><xRef value="D16CAC9590D8A1D2E379FD9664B0E933"/></xField></xConstructor><fadeInObject><target><ref value="91654A932687B34BB4B7FC31E9C9616A"/></target></fadeInObject><fadeInObject><target><ref value="CD662BB134A97E6B7C298C6583B8FEF2"/></target></fadeInObject><fadeInObject><target><ref value="F0A109379CC374F86CD7B74DE765AB9F"/></target></fadeInObject><fadeInObject><target><ref value="82BEDE3D36BBFB063FB7EA6EE3C473B6"/></target></fadeInObject><fadeInObject><target><ref value="65C4800C880641C96DDB44D38986DCEE"/></target></fadeInObject><fadeInObject><target><ref value="6103674737D84E3ADB89DFA602F2D91A"/></target></fadeInObject><xConstructor name="zoomToObject" type="pathAction"><xField name="target"><xRef value="40D651F5CF5FD3A201A0380F9C0460A6"/></xField></xConstructor></array></actions><target><ref value="40D651F5CF5FD3A201A0380F9C0460A6"/></target></flyToObject><flyToObject><xFields><xField name="narrative"><xJust><xConstructor type="narrative" name="plainTextNarrative"><xField name="text"><xString value="Last step I would like to mention is integration testing
Created a framework for that

It is a DSL for writing integration tests, it is trying to be human readable and you can write down any kind of multi-user collaborative editing scenarios with it.
It controls the editor with webdriver
It contains all the other microservices our service is using in docker containers
It can even load different versions of PDOM libraries to test how they work together
Very important: support for failure injection - testing reconnects, etc.
Test with the destop app
Haskell example"/></xField></xConstructor></xJust></xField></xFields><actions><array><fadeInObject><target><ref value="0AB355DC89BA86A85C0BEE44696F0666"/></target></fadeInObject><fadeInObject><target><ref value="2A36BFD17F5367E242B001783770B3E3"/></target></fadeInObject><fadeInObject><target><ref value="E16B3C48309CF6F66B91B9E7C21BE7EC"/></target></fadeInObject><fadeInObject><target><ref value="65DCA672BADFBAA21F541B213283A6F5"/></target></fadeInObject><fadeInObject><target><ref value="C1B789C97BDAEBFD2D5984873AEF3B7E"/></target></fadeInObject><fadeInObject><target><ref value="A177F9369FA6C651C878A48E0107874A"/></target></fadeInObject><fadeInObject><target><ref value="834690320"/></target></fadeInObject><xConstructor name="zoomToObject" type="pathAction"><xField name="target"><xRef value="834690320"/></xField></xConstructor><xConstructor name="zoomToObject" type="pathAction"><xField name="target"><xRef value="3A2781542F0E987AEBC6EB62F91095CE"/></xField></xConstructor></array></actions><target><ref value="3A2781542F0E987AEBC6EB62F91095CE"/></target></flyToObject><flyToOverview><xFields><xField name="narrative"><xJust><xConstructor type="narrative" name="plainTextNarrative"><xField name="text"><xString value="Hi, thanks for coming, I'm Daniel Vigovszky..
I'm going to talk today about how we use Scala to keep our document system consistent on all platforms while it is continously evolving.
"/></xField></xConstructor></xJust></xField></xFields></flyToOverview><flyToObject><xFields><xField name="narrative"><xJust><xConstructor type="narrative" name="plainTextNarrative"><xField name="text"><xString value="Finally let me summarize what I think are reusable from all this for you

First tip: make use of ScalaCheck, it really helped us to find tons of problems

If you have multiple platforms and have to implement something on all of them (like the DOM in our case), try to have a single source of truth, for example by code generation

or by using one platforms' implementation somehow in others, like what we did with the arbitraries for multi-platform tests

Failure simulation is very important"/></xField></xConstructor></xJust></xField></xFields><actions><array><fadeInObject><target><ref value="D1AA57875BEBB93A740A5C6630438EC0"/></target></fadeInObject><fadeInObject><target><ref value="CE35F9DD15DC217FEB4F6100593E2E86"/></target></fadeInObject><fadeInObject><target><ref value="DF9ED9B15515B48B82206068C0382D5E"/></target></fadeInObject><fadeInObject><target><ref value="AAA23878AF111A47023CA84D4B193A3A"/></target></fadeInObject><fadeInObject><target><ref value="78BB50AFC7DD1E71B97B25F421C5FFB4"/></target></fadeInObject></array></actions><target><ref value="4E2135AF852F811525544158435BB7DD"/></target></flyToObject><flyToOverview><xFields><xField name="narrative"><xJust><xConstructor type="narrative" name="plainTextNarrative"><xField name="text"><xString value="Hi, thanks for coming, I'm Daniel Vigovszky..
